Unrest in Chile causes the Copa Libertadores final to be moved out of the country
The Chilean capital is characterized by noise and turmoil. Now the final of Copa Libertadores which was to go in Santiago will be moved to Lima in Peru.
06 Nov 2019, 07:44 by NTB-Ritzau-AFP
There have been violent protests and political unrest in Chile and Santiago over the past month. That is why the South American Football Association, Conmebol, has chosen to move the Copa Libertadores final to Lima.
Conmebol said in a meeting in Paraguay on Tuesday that the current situation in Chile will put players and spectators at risk. The final between the Argentine River Plate and Brazilian Flamengo is set for Saturday, November 23, as scheduled.
- The decision is based on the offer the government in Peru has made and that they have guaranteed the security, says a press release from the federation.

The football team does not exclude Haaland sales after the crazy goal show



These are wild conditions in the Chilean capital. That's why they chose to move the Copa Libertadores final from Santiago to Lima in Peru.üì∑ Photo: Esteban Felix / AP / NTB scanpix

The Chile-Bolivia international battle, which was to take place on November 15 in Santiago, has been canceled due to the unrest.
Initially, there was an announced price increase on public transport in Chile that triggered the extensive demonstrations. They started on October 20 and have evolved to deal with inequalities in the rest of the country.
So far, at least 20 people have been killed in the riots and more than 7,000 have been brought in by police. The unrest has also led to Chile having to cancel an international climate summit in Santiago.
Last year, the Copa Libertadores final also had to be moved after an attack on a player bus in Buenos Aires when River Plate and Boca Juniors were to meet.
That final had to be played in Madrid a couple of weeks late. River Plate is the title defender.
